sen.j: 橋姫（はしひめ）は、橋にまつわる伝承に現れる女性・鬼女・女神である。
sen.e: Hashihime is a lady, ogress or goddess appeared in folklore about bridges.
Hashihime is a lady, ogress or goddess who appears in legends about bridges.
Hashihime is a lady, ogress or goddess who appears in legends about bridges.

sen.j: 宇治の橋姫とも。
sen.e: She is also called Uji no Hashihime.
She is also called Uji no Hashihime.
She is also called Uji no Hashihime.

sen.j: 多様な伝承と側面を持ち、主なものに源綱が一条戻り橋で遭遇し斬った「嫉妬の鬼」、宇治橋そばの橋姫神社に祭られている「橋の守り神」、の2つがある。
sen.e: She has various folklore and aspects, and the two major ones are 'Jealous ogress,' encountered and killed by MINAMOTO no Tsuna at the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge, and 'Guardian deity of the bridge,' enshrined in Hashihime-jinja Shrine near the Uji-bashi Bridge.

She appears in many legends and has various aspects, but the two major ones are the 'Jealous ogress' encountered and killed by MINAMOTO no Tsuna at Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge, and the 'Guardian deity of the bridge' enshrined in Hashihime-jinja Shrine near Uji-bashi Bridge.

She appears in many legends and has various aspects, but the two major ones are the 'Jealous ogress' encountered and killed by MINAMOTO no Tsuna at Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge, and the 'Guardian deity of the bridge' enshrined in Hashihime-jinja Shrine near Uji-bashi Bridge.

sen.j: 文献
sen.e: Literature
Literature
Literature

sen.j: 古今和歌集
sen.e: Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry)
Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry)
Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry)

sen.j: 古くは、『古今和歌集』 (905年) 第14巻の詠み人知らずの和歌に現れる。
sen.e: She appeared in an anonymous waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) in the 14th volume in "Kokin Wakashu" (905) in ancient times.
She appeared in an anonymous waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) in the 14th volume of the ancient "Kokin Wakashu" (905).
She appeared in an anonymous waka (a traditional Japanese poem of 31 syllables) in the 14th volume of the ancient "Kokin Wakashu" (905).

sen.j: 歌の世界ではしばしば、伝説と異なり、橋姫は愛らしい女性としてロマンチックな歌に現れた。
sen.e: In the world of poetry, she often appeared as an adorable lady in romantic poems, different from her legend.
In poetry, in contrast to the legends, she is often appears in romantic poems as an adorable lady.
In poetry, in contrast to the legends, she often appears in romantic poems as an adorable lady.

sen.j: 平家物語
sen.e: Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike)
Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike)
Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike)

sen.j: 嫉妬に狂う鬼としての橋姫が現れるのは、『平家物語』の読み本系異本の『源平盛衰記』・『屋台本』などに収録されている「剣巻」で、橋姫の物語の多くの原型となっている。
sen.e: Hashihime appeared as an ogress with jealous rage in 'Tsurugi no maki' (Chapter of Sword) included in reading books such as "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans) or "Yashirobon" (unauthorized book) as an alternative version of "Heike Monogatari", which became the original of the most Hashihime stories.
sen.cmt: 「屋台本」が登録ではYataibonとなっていますが、これは本来「屋代本」で、Yashirobonと読むようです。http://www.toride.com/~yuga/heike/yashiro.html
sen.e: Hashihime appears as an ogress filled with jealousy in 'Tsurugi no maki' (Chapter of the Sword) in Edo-period alternative versions of "Heike Monogatari" such as "Genpei Seisui ki" (The Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and Taira Clans) or "Yashirobon" (unauthorized book), which became the basis for most Hashihime stories.

Hashihime appears as an ogress filled with jealousy in 'Tsurugi no maki' (Chapter of the Sword) in alternative versions of "Heike Monogatari" such as "Genpei Seisui ki" (The Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and Taira Clans) or "Yashirobon" (unauthorized book), which became the basis for most Hashihime stories.

sen.j: 異本であるため、出版されている『平家物語全集』の類の多くには収録されていない。
sen.e: It is not included in the most of "Complete works of Heike Monogatari" and the same sorts published, because it is an alternative version.
Since it is an alternative version, it is not included in most books of "The Complete Heike Monogatari" kind.
Since it is an alternative version, it is not included in most books of "The Complete Heike Monogatari" kind.

sen.j: 大意は次のとおり。
sen.e: The summary is as shown below.
The story can be summarized as follows.
The story can be summarized as follows.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇の御世（809年-825年）、とある公卿の娘が、深い妬みにとらわれ、貴船神社に7日間籠ってこう祈った。
sen.e: During the reign of Emperor Saga (809-825), a daughter of a Court noble was captured by envy, and stuck inside the Kibune-jinja Shrine for seven days to pray as below.
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: During the reign of Emperor Saga (809-825), a daughter of a Court noble who had became filled with envy shut herself away in Kibune-jinja Shrine, praying,
During the reign of Emperor Saga (809-825), a daughter of a Court noble who had become filled with envy shut herself away in Kibune-jinja Shrine, praying,

sen.j: 「貴船大明神よ、私を生きながら鬼神に変えてください。」
sen.e: Kibune Daimyojin, please change me into Kijin (ogre god) while I am still alive.'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: O Great Myojin God of Kibune, please change me into a Kijin (ogre god) while I am still alive."
O Great Myojin God of Kibune, please change me into a Kijin (ogre god) while I am still alive."

sen.j: 「妬ましい女を取り殺したいのです。」
sen.e: I want to possess and kill a woman I envy.'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: "I want to possess and kill a woman I envy."
"I want to possess and kill a woman I envy."

sen.j: 明神は哀れに思い「本当に鬼になりたければ、姿を変えて宇治川に21日間ひたれ」と告げた。
sen.e: The Myojin God felt sorry and told her 'If you really want to become an ogress, transform yourself and soak in the Uji-gawa River for 21 day.'
The Myojin God felt sorry and told her, "If you really want to become an ogress, change your appearance and soak in the Uji-gawa River for 21 days."
The Myojin God felt sorry and told her, "If you really want to become an ogress, change your appearance and soak in the Uji-gawa River for 21 days."

sen.j: 女は平安京に帰ると、髪を5つに分け5本の角にし、顔には辰砂をさし体には鉛丹を塗って全身を赤くし、鉄輪（てつわ、鉄の輪に三本脚が付いた台）を逆さに頭に載せ、3本の脚には松明を燃やし、さらに両端を燃やした松明を口にくわえ、計5つの火を灯した。
sen.e: After the woman went back to Heiankyo (ancient capital in current Kyoto), she made five horns by separating her hair in five parts; put cinnabar on her face and red lead paint on her body to make the full body red; put Tetsuwa (a stand with an iron ring and three-legged support) on her head upside down; lit torches on the three legs and put a torch burning at both ends into her mouth, which made five fires lit in total.
sen.cmt: サイト上でも「てつわ」となっているのでそのままにしましたが、通常「かなわ」と読むようですし、後列では「かなわ」というのが出てきます。
sen.e: After the woman returned to Heiankyo (the former name of Kyoto), she made five horns by separating her hair into five parts, she painted herself red by putting cinnabar on her face and red lead paint on her body, put a tetsuwa (a three-legged iron stand) upside down on her head, put lit torches on the three legs and put a torch burning at both ends into her mouth, making five fires in total.

After the woman returned to Heiankyo (the former name of Kyoto), she made five horns by separating her hair into five parts, she painted herself red by putting cinnabar on her face and red lead paint on her body, put a tetsuwa (a three-legged iron stand) upside down on her head, put lit torches on the three legs and put a torch burning at both ends into her mouth, making five fires in total.

sen.j: 夜が更けると大和大路を南へ走り、それを見た人はその鬼のような姿を見たショックで倒れて死んでしまった。
sen.e: She ran south on Yamatooji street late at night, and those who saw her fell and died of shock seeing such an ogre-like figure.
Late that night, she ran south on Yamato-oji Street, and those who saw her fell and died of shock at seeing such an ogre-like figure.
Late that night, she ran south on Yamato-oji Street, and those who saw her fell and died of shock at seeing such an ogre-like figure.

sen.j: そのようにして宇治川に21日間ひたると、貴船大明神の言ったとおり生きながら鬼になった。
sen.e: Then she soaked in the Uji-gawa river for 21 days, and she became an ogre while she was still alive as Kibune Daimyojin said.
Then she soaked in the Uji-gawa river for 21 days and, as Kibune Daimyojin had said, she became an ogre while she was still alive.
Then she soaked in the Uji-gawa river for 21 days and, as Kibune Daimyojin had said, she became an ogre while she was still alive.
sen.cmt: as の後のスペース短縮

sen.j: これが「宇治の橋姫」である。
sen.e: This is 'Uji no Hashihime.'
This is 'Uji no Hashihime.'
This is 'Uji no Hashihime.'

sen.j: 橋姫は、妬んでいた女、その縁者、相手の男のほうの親類、しまいには誰彼かまわず、次々と殺した。
sen.e: She killed the woman she envied, her relatives, relatives of her man, and anybody successively in the end.
She killed the woman she envied, then the woman's relatives, the relatives of the woman's man, and finally just anybody.
She killed the woman she envied, then the woman's relatives, the relatives of the woman's man, and finally just anybody.

sen.j: 男を殺すときは女の姿、女を殺すときは男の姿になって殺していった。
sen.e: She became a woman when she killed a man, and a man when killing a woman.
She became a woman when killing men, and a man when killing women.
She became a woman when killing men, and a man when killing women.

sen.j: 京中の者が、申の時（15～17時ごろ）を過ぎると家に人を入れることも外出することもなくなった。
sen.e: All the people in the Kyoto stopped both letting someone into the house and going out after the hour of the Monkey (between 15:00 and 17:00).
The people of Kyoto stopped both letting someone into the house and going out after the Hour of the Monkey (from 15:00 to 17:00).
The people of Kyoto stopped both letting someone into the house and going out after the Hour of the Monkey (from 15:00 to 17:00).

sen.j: そうしたころ、源頼光の頼光四天王の1人源綱が一条大宮に遣わされた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, MINAMOTO no Tsuna, one of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu's Yorimitsu Shitenno (the four loyal retainers of Yorimitsu), was dispatched to Ichijo Omiya.
Meanwhile, MINAMOTO no Tsuna, one of the Shitenno (four loyal retainers) of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, was sent to the Ichijo Omiya intersection.
sen.cmt: I presume 一条大宮 was the corner of 一条大路 and 大宮大路, which was on the eastern side of the Imperial Palace, but I don't know what stood there.
sen.e: Meanwhile, MINAMOTO no Tsuna, one of the Shitenno (four loyal retainers) of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, was sent to the Ichijo Omiya.

sen.j: 夜は（橋姫のせいで）危険なので、名刀「鬚切（ひげきり）」をあずかり、馬で向かった。
sen.e: Since it was dangerous (because of Hashihime) at night, he was given a celebrated sword 'Higekiri (literally, cutting beard),' and he left on a horse.
Since it was dangerous at night (because of Hashihime), he was given the celebrated sword 'Higekiri' (literally, 'beard cutter'), and then left on horseback.
Since it was dangerous at night (because of Hashihime), he was given the celebrated sword 'Higekiri' (literally, 'beard cutter'), and then left on horseback.

sen.j: その帰り道、一条戻橋を渡るとき、女性を見つけた。
sen.e: On the way back, he found a woman when he crossed the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge.
On the way back, he came across a woman as he crossed the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge.
On the way back, he came across a woman as he crossed the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge.

sen.j: 見たところ20歳余で、肌は雪のように白く、紅梅柄の打衣を着て、お経を持って、一人で南へ向かっていた。
sen.e: She seemed over 20 years old with white skin as snow, and she was heading south alone, wearing uchiginu (a beaten scarlet silk robe worn as a stiffener and support for the outer robes) with a rose plum pattern and carrying a Buddhist sutra.

She seemed to be over 20 years old withskin as white as snow, and she was heading south alone, wearing an uchiginu (a beaten silk robe worn usually worn as support for the outer robes) with a rose plum pattern and carrying a Buddhist sutra.

She seemed to be over 20 years old with skin as white as snow, and she was heading south alone, wearing an uchiginu (a beaten silk robe usually worn as support for the outer robes) with a rose plum pattern and carrying a Buddhist sutra.

sen.j: 綱は「夜は危ないので、五条通まで送りましょう」と言って、自分は馬から降りて女を乗せ、堀川 (京都府)東岸を南に向かった。
sen.e: Tsuna told her 'it is dangerous at night, so I will escort you to Gojo-dori Street,' and he got off the horse and mount her on the horse, then headed south along the east bank of the Hori-kawa River (Kyoto).
Tsuna told her, "It is dangerous at night, so I will escort you to Gojo-dori Street," and he got off his horse so she could ride, then headed south along the east bank of the Hori-kawa River.
Tsuna told her, "It is dangerous at night, so I will escort you to Gojo-dori Street," and he got off his horse so she could ride, then headed south along the east bank of the Hori-kawa River.
sen.cmt: 会話文のため、"" のままとします。

sen.j: 正親町の近くで女が「実は家は都の外なのですが、送ってくださらないでしょうか」と頼んだので、綱はこうこたえた。
sen.e: Near Ogicho, the woman asked 'Actually I live outside the capital, but would you take me home?,' so Tsuna answered as below.
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: Near Ogicho, the woman asked, "Actually I live outside the capital, but would you take me home?," to which Tsuna answered,
Near Ogicho, the woman asked, "Actually I live outside the capital, but would you take me home?," to which Tsuna answered as follows.
sen.cmt: 会話文のため、"" のままとします。文末を as follows としました。

sen.j: 「わかりました。」
sen.e: All right.'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: "All right,
sen.cmt: *I think these two sentences are one so revised punctuation
sen.e: "All right."
sen.cmt: 会話文のため、"" のままとし、独立した一文に戻しました。

sen.j: 「お送りします。」
sen.e: I will take you home.'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: I will take you home."
sen.cmt: *I think these two sentences are one so revised punctuation
sen.e: "I will take you home."
sen.cmt: 会話文のため、"" のままとし、独立した一文に戻しました。

sen.j: すると女は鬼の姿に変わり、「愛宕山 (京都市)へ行きましょう」と言って綱の髪をつかんで北西へ飛びたった。
sen.e: Then the woman transformed into an ogress, seized Tsuna by the hair and flew northwest, saying 'Let's go to Mt. Atago.'
At this, the woman transformed into an ogress, seized Tsuna by the hair and flew northwest, saying, "Let's go to Mt. Atago."
At this, the woman transformed into an ogress, seized Tsuna by the hair and flew northwest, saying, "Let's go to Mt. Atago (Kyoto City)."
sen.cmt: 「（京都市）」訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: 綱はあわてず、鬚切で鬼の腕を断ち斬った。
sen.e: Tsuna cut the ogress' arm by Higekiri without panic.
Tsuna calmly cut off the ogress' arm with Higekiri.
Tsuna calmly cut off the ogress' arm with Higekiri.

sen.j: 綱は北野の社に落ち、鬼は手を斬られたまま愛宕へ飛んでいった。
sen.e: Tsuna fell into a shrine in Kitano, and the ogress flew to Atago with the arm cut.
Tsuna fell into a shrine in Kitano, and the ogress flew to Atago without her arm.
Tsuna fell into a shrine in Kitano, and the ogress flew to Atago without her arm.

sen.j: 綱が、髪をつかんでいた鬼の腕を手に取って見ると、雪のように白かったはずが、真っ黒で、銀の針を立てたように白い体毛がびっしり生えていた。
sen.e: When Tsuna picked up and looked at the ogress' arm that was holding the hair, it was jet-black with thick white skin hair like silver needles, although it seemed to be white as snow.
When Tsuna picked up the arm that had been grasping his hair, he saw that it was actually jet-black and covered in needle-like white hairs, which was why it had seemed to be white as snow.
When Tsuna picked up the arm that had been grasping his hair, he saw that it was actually jet-black and covered in needle-like white hairs, which was why it had seemed to be white as snow.

sen.j: 鬼の腕を頼光に見せると頼光は大いに驚き、安倍晴明を呼んでどうすればいいか問うた。
sen.e: When seeing the ogress' arm, Yorimitsu was greatly surprised, and called ABE no Seimei to ask what to do.
When he showed the arm to Yorimitsu, Yorimitsu was greatly surprised and called ABE no Seimei to ask what to do.
When he showed the arm to Yorimitsu, Yorimitsu was greatly surprised and called ABE no Seimei to ask what to do.

sen.j: 晴明がこう言った。
sen.e: Seimei said as below.
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: Seimei told him:
Seimei told him as follows.
sen.cmt: 文末を as follows としました。

sen.j: 「綱は7日間休暇を取って謹慎してください。」
sen.e: Tsuna must take seven days off and stay home.'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: "Tsuna must take seven days off and stay home.
sen.cmt: *I think these two sentences are one so revised punctuation
sen.e: "Tsuna must take seven days off and stay home."
sen.cmt: punctuation をつけました。会話文のため""です。

sen.j: 「鬼の腕は私が仁王経を読んで封印します」
sen.e: I will seal up the ogress' arm by chanting Ninnogyo (the Sutra of Benevolent Kings).'
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: I will place a seal on the ogress' arm by chanting the Ninnogyo (Sutra of Benevolent Kings)."
sen.cmt: *I think these two sentences are one so revised punctuation
sen.e: "I will place a seal on the ogress' arm by chanting the Ninnogyo (Sutra of Benevolent Kings)."
sen.cmt: punctuation をつけました。会話文のため""です。

sen.j: それで、そのとおりにさせた。
sen.e: So he had him do that.
sen.cmt: 「」内の文なので分割しました。
sen.e: Yorimitsu followed his advice.
Yorimitsu followed his advice.

sen.j: 橋姫の腕を斬った「鬚切」は実在し現存する日本刀。
sen.e: The Japanese sword 'Higekiri' which cut Hashihime's arm was and is still existent.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Japanese sword 'Higekiri' which cut Hashihime's arm was real and still exists.
The Japanese sword 'Higekiri' which cut Hashihime's arm was real and still exists.

sen.j: この事件により「鬼切（おにきり）」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: It began to be called 'Onikiri (literally cutting ogre)' after this incident.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It began to be called 'Onikiri' (literally 'ogre cutter') after this incident.
It began to be called 'Onikiri' (literally 'ogre cutter') after this incident.

sen.j: 綱の羅城門の鬼退治（『酒呑童子』）や多田満仲の戸隠山の鬼退治（『太平記』）などにも使われたとされる。
sen.e: It is said that it was also used for an Ogre extermination at the Rasho-mon Gate by Tsuna ("Shuten Doji" (the leader of a group of bandits that roamed the region around Kyoto) and another at Mt. Togakushi by TADA no Manju ("Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that it was also used by Tsuna to kill an ogre ("Shuten Doji" - the leader of a group of local bandits) at the Rasho-mon Gate and also by TADA no Manju to kill the ogre of Mt. Togakushi ("Taiheiki", The Record of the Great Peace).

It is said that it was also used by Tsuna to kill an ogre ("Shuten Doji" - the leader of a group of local bandits) at the Rajo-mon Gate and also by TADA no Manju to kill the ogre of Mt. Togakushi ("Taiheiki", The Record of the Great Peace).
sen.cmt: Rasho-mon→Rajo-monkill の前のスペース短縮

sen.j: 鬼と縁が深い名刀である。
sen.e: It is a celebrated sword deeply related with ogres.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is a celebrated sword and is deeply connected to ogres.
It is a celebrated sword and is deeply connected to ogres.

sen.j: 橋姫がひたった川は宇治川で、祭られているのは宇治川の宇治橋である。
sen.e: The river Hashihime soaked was the Uji-gawa River, and she is enshrined at the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The river Hashihime soaked in was the Uji-gawa River, and she is enshrined at the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.
The river Hashihime soaked in was the Uji-gawa River, and she is enshrined at the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.

sen.j: だが、綱が橋姫と出合ったのは堀川の一条戻り橋である。
sen.e: However, it was the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge over the Hori-kawa River where Tsuna met Hashihime.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it was the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge over the Hori-kawa River where Tsuna met Hashihime.
However, it was the Ichijo Modori-bashi Bridge over the Hori-kawa River where Tsuna met Hashihime.

sen.j: 歳月の経過は特に描写されていない。
sen.e: The course of time is not specifically described.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: How much time passed between the two events is not specifically described.
How much time passed between the two events is not specifically described.

sen.j: だが、源頼光・源綱・安倍晴明の時代は「嵯峨天皇の御宇」の200年近く後である。
sen.e: But the period of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Tsuna and ABE no Seimei was almost two hundred years later than 'the reign of Emperor Saga.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Tsuna and ABE no Seimei lived almost two hundred years after 'the reign of Emperor Saga.'
But MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, MINAMOTO no Tsuna and ABE no Seimei lived almost 200 years after 'the reign of Emperor Saga.'

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Others
Others
Others

sen.j: 『太平記』、『橋姫物語』にもその名が見える。
sen.e: Her name is appeared in "Taiheiki" and "Tale of Hashihime."
Her name also appears in "Taiheiki" and "Tale of Hashihime."
Her name also appears in "Taiheiki" and "Tale of Hashihime."

sen.j: 鉄輪
sen.e: Kanawa
Kanawa
Kanawa

sen.j: 『平家物語』の「剣巻」を元に話を膨らませた能の演目『鉄輪（かなわ）』がある。
sen.e: There is a Noh program named "Kanawa," an expanded story from 'Tsurugi no maki' of "Heike Monogatari."
There is a Noh program named "Kanawa," an expanded version of the 'Tsurugi no maki' from the "Heike Monogatari"
There is a Noh program named "Kanawa," an expanded version of the 'Tsurugi no maki' from the "Heike Monogatari"

sen.j: 橋姫が頭にかぶった鉄輪から名が取られている。
sen.e: It was named after the Kanawa Hashihime put on her head.
It is named after the tripod Hashihime put on her head.
It is named after the tripod Hashihime put on her head.

sen.j: 橋姫は、後妻に夫を奪われた女性となっている。
sen.e: Hashihime is described as a woman who was deprived of her husband by his second wife.
Hashihime is portrayed as a woman whose husband is stolen by another woman.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: Hashihime is portrayed as a woman whose husband is stolen by another woman.

sen.j: 元夫と後妻は、呪い殺される寸前で怪異に気づいた。
sen.e: Her husband and his second wife noticed mysterious phenomena, when they were almost cursed and killed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Her husband and his second wife begin to notice mysterious phenomena before being almost killed by a curse.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: Her husband and his second wife begin to notice mysterious phenomena before being almost killed by a curse.

sen.j: 安倍晴明に相談すると、このままでは今夜までの命と告げられた。
sen.e: They consulted with ABE no Seimei, and he told them that they would be dead by the night if this went on.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They consult ABE no Seimei, who tells them that they will be dead by tonight if this continues.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: They consult ABE no Seimei, who tells them that they will be dead by tonight if this continues.

sen.j: 晴明は夫婦に頼まれ、形代（身代わりの人形）を使った呪い代えを試みると、鬼女が姿を現した。
sen.e: Asked by the couple, Seimei tried curse transfer using katashiro (scapegoat dolls), and then the ogress appeared.
Asked by the couple, Seimei tries to transfer the curse to katashiro (dolls representing the couple), and then the ogress appears.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: Asked by the couple, Seimei tries to transfer the curse to katashiro (dolls representing the couple), and then the ogress appears.

sen.j: その姿は、川での儀式のときと同じ、鉄輪や松明をつけた姿であった。
sen.e: She was dressed with Kanawa and torches, just like on the occasion of the ceremony at the river.
She is dressed with a kanawa and torches, just like on the occasion of the ceremony at the river.
She is dressed with a kanawa and torches, just like on the occasion of the ceremony at the river.

sen.j: 舞台では、嫉妬と復讐心に顔を歪める女性の能面「橋姫」が使われる。
sen.e: On the stage, Noh mask 'Hashihime,' representing a woman making a face at jealousy and revenge is used.
On the stage, the 'Hashihime' mask used depicts a female face distorted with jealousy and desire for revenge.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: On the stage, the 'Hashihime' mask used depicts a female face distorted with jealousy and desire for revenge.

sen.j: 橋姫は夫婦に襲い掛かるが、晴明と三十番神に撃退され、「時期を待つ」と言い残して消えていった。
sen.e: Hashihime attacked the couple, but she was beaten back by Seimei and Sanjubanshin (thirty guardian deities), so she disappeared, saying 'I will wait and see.'
Hashihime attacks the couple, but is beaten back by Seimei and Sanju-banshin (thirty guardian deities), so she disappears, saying 'I will bide my time.'
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - as this tells a story that is still acted out today, I changed it to the present tense
sen.e: Hashihime attacks the couple, but is beaten back by Seimei and Sanju-banshin (30 guardian deities), so she disappears, saying 'I will bide my time.'

sen.j: 剣巻で重要登場人物だった源綱は登場しない。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tsuna, who was an important character in Tsurugi no maki doesn't appear.
MINAMOTO no Tsuna, who was an important character in the 'Tsurugi no maki', doesn't appear.
MINAMOTO no Tsuna, who was an important character in the 'Tsurugi no maki', doesn't appear.

sen.j: 丑の刻参り
sen.e: Ushi no koku mairi (a visit to a shrine at dead of night to put a curse of death on somebody)
Ushi no koku mairi (visiting a shrine in the dead of night to put a curse of death on somebody)
Ushi no koku mairi (visiting a shrine in the dead of night to put a curse of death on somebody)

sen.j: 橋姫がおこなった呪いの儀式が、丑の刻参りのルーツである。
sen.e: Ushi no koku mairi originates from the curse ceremony Hashihime held.
Ushi no koku mairi originates from the curse ceremony Hashihime held.
Ushi no koku mairi originates from the curse ceremony Hashihime held.

sen.j: 橋姫神社
sen.e: Hashihime-jinja Shrine
Hashihime-jinja Shrine
Hashihime-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 宇治川に架かる宇治橋の近くに橋姫神社がある。
sen.e: Hashihime-jinja Shrine is located near the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.
Hashihime-jinja Shrine is located near the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.
Hashihime-jinja Shrine is located near the Uji-bashi Bridge over the Uji-gawa River.

sen.j: 正式には、上流から遷祀されたとされる瀬織津媛（せおりつひめ）を祭っている。
sen.e: Seoritsuhime, who is said to have been transferred from the upper reaches is officially enshrined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It officially enshrines Seoritsuhime, who is said to have been transferred from up river.
It officially enshrines Seoritsuhime, who is said to have been transferred from up river.

sen.j: しかし、『平家物語』などでの橋姫と同一視されている。
sen.e: However, she was regarded same as Hashihime in "Heike Monogatari."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the "Heike Monogatari", she is regarded as being the same as Hashihime.
However, in the "Heike Monogatari", she is regarded as being the same as Hashihime.

sen.j: 源綱に討たれた後に橋の神になったという話もある。
sen.e: Another story is that she became a deity of a bridge after she was beaten by MINAMOTO no Tsuna.
Another story is that she became the deity of the bridge after being defeated by MINAMOTO no Tsuna.
Another story is that she became the deity of the bridge after being defeated by MINAMOTO no Tsuna.

sen.j: 橋を守る女神として祭られているが、縁切りの神でもあり、悪縁を切るご利益がある。
sen.e: Though she was enshrined as a deity protecting a bridge, she was also a deity of separation answering the prayer to get rid of bad relationship.
Though she was enshrined as a bridge-protecting deity, she is also a deity of separation, who answers prayers to end bad relationships.
Though she was enshrined as a bridge-protecting deity, she is also a deity of separation, who answers prayers to end bad relationships.

sen.j: 逆に、恋人同士や婚礼の儀で、神社の前を通ったり宇治橋を渡ったりするのはタブーである。
sen.e: On the contrary, it is taboo for a couple or a wedding to walk past the shrine or to cross the Uji-bashi Bridge.
However, couples and wedding parties should also avoid walking past the shrine or crossing the Uji-bashi Bridge.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - although the Japanese has "タブー", I think the nuance is that it's not recommended rather than it's morally unacceptable.
sen.e: However, couples and wedding parties should also avoid walking past the shrine or crossing the Uji-bashi Bridge.
